citations.narrative:
The primary enclosures that house three zebu, one cavy, one wallaby, one camel, and one water buffalo are not
contained within an 6ft tall perimeter fence. The perimeter fence height can lead to unnecessary animal escapes and
contact between humans and other animals with the animals contained at the facility that could lead to injury or disease.
All outdoor housing facilities must be enclosed by a perimeter fence that is of sufficient height to keep animals and
unauthorized persons out. Correct by maintaining a perimeter fence around the enclosures that is at least 6 feet tall and 3
feet away from the primary enclosures. Fences less than 6 feet high for other animals must be approved in writing by the
Administrator. The fence must be constructed so that it protects the animals in the facility by restricting animals and
unauthorized persons from going through it or under it and having contact with the animals in the facility, and so that it can
function as a secondary containment system for the animals in the facility.
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by February 4, 2024 or the applicant will forfeit the license
fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
n

narrative:
3.127(d) 
   
Facilities, outdoor. 
The primary enclosures that house three zebu, one cavy, one wallaby, one camel, and one water buffalo are not 
contained within an 6ft tall perimeter fence. The perimeter fence height can lead to unnecessary animal escapes and 
contact between humans and other animals with the animals contained at the facility that could lead to injury or disease.  
All outdoor housing facilities must be enclosed by a perimeter fence that is of sufficient height to keep animals and 
unauthorized persons out. Correct by maintaining a perimeter fence around the enclosures that is at least 6 feet tall and 3 
feet away from the primary enclosures. Fences less than 6 feet high for other animals must be approved  in writing by the 
Administrator. The fence must be constructed so that it protects the animals in the facility by restricting animals and 
unauthorized persons from going through it or under it and having contact with the animals in the facility, and so that it can 
function as a secondary containment system for the animals in the facility. 
 
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the 
applicant. 
 
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by February 4, 2024 or the applicant will forfeit the license 
fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection. 
 
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
